name: Elementary Classical Greek I
desc: Comprehensive coverage of basic grammar and syntax in two semesters, preparing students for reading Plato or Xenophon in GREK 203 (and with the instructor's permission, New Testament Greek in GREK 205).

name: Elementary Classical Greek II
desc: Comprehensive coverage of basic grammar and syntax in two semesters, preparing students for reading Plato or Xenophon in GREK 203 (and with the instructor's permission, New Testament Greek in GREK 205).

name: Intermediate Greek I
desc: Review of fundamentals; reading primarily in selected prose texts, such as Xenophon, Plato, Lysias, or others.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, GREK 101 and 102; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.

name: Intermediate Greek II
desc: Reading primarily in selected poetic texts, such as Homer, Euripides, or others.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, GREK 203; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Introductory Greek New Testament
desc: Readings from the Greek New Testament and related texts, with particular attention to grammar and syntax and consideration of their literary and cultural context.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, GREK 203; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Advanced Greek I
desc: Readings from classical Greek poetry or prose, with attention to their syntax, style, and cultural and historical context.
Prereqs: Prerequisites, GREK 204 or 205; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Advanced Greek II
desc: Readings from classical Greek poetry or prose, with attention to their syntax, style, and cultural and historical context.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, GREK 221; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Classical Greek Prose
desc: Readings in Herodotus, Thucydides, Plato, or other authors, with attention to their style and cultural/historical context. With permission of the department, this course may be repeated for credit.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, GREK 221 or 222; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Greek Poetry
desc: Readings from Homer, Greek tragedy, or other Greek poetry. With permission of the department, this course may be repeated for credit.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, GREK 221 or 222; permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Independent Research in Greek
desc: This course allows a student to design and execute an independent research project under the supervision of a faculty member.  Although the specifics will be determined on a case-by-case basis by the student and the faculty supervisor, the project will normally involve the careful study of key primary sources and engagement with relevant scholarship, and culminate in a major research paper (around 25 pages) or a suitable equivalent in another format (e.g., website, video). Permission of the Instructor.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Special Readings in Greek Literature
desc: Prerequisite, GREK 222.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Greek New Testament
desc: Prerequisite, GREK 222; Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.

name: Greek Prose Composition
desc: Review of Attic grammar and idiom, exercises in composition, introduction to stylistics.

name: Readings in Early Greek Poetry
desc: Selections from Homer, Hesiod, and/or the lyric and elegiac poets of the Archaic period, focusing on works on the M.A. and Ph.D. reading lists.

name: Readings in Greek Literature of the Fifth Century
desc: Selections from tragedy, Old Comedy, and/or historiography, focusing on works on the M.A. and Ph.D. reading lists.

name: Readings in Greek Literature of the Fourth Century
desc: Selections from philosophy, oratory, historiography, and/or New Comedy, focusing on works on the M.A. and Ph.D. reading lists.

name: An Introduction To Greek Law
desc: This class has three goals: familiarizing students with Greek language, introducing them to concepts of Greek law by reading secondary literature, and directing them to current debates in the field.

name: Special Reading
desc: With permission of the department, this course may be repeated for credit.

name: Greek Seminiars
desc: Topics vary from year to year.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics.

name: Master's Research and Thesis
desc: Fall and spring. Staff.

name: Doctoral Research and Dissertation
desc: Fall and spring. Staff.
